ratings.comment: Great lecture without very hard homework and exams!
He runs out of the classroom the moment the lecture is supposed to be over because he is afraid of being held accountable for anything he spewed out over the last 50 minutes.
worst math class I ever take in UWMadison. Homework problem are partially graded since "not enough grader". And the exam was not related to the material covered in class

I would give a 0/5 if I could He skips steps more than I can skip a stone on a lake the lowest score on the final was lower than the mid term he explanation is worse than a street vendor explaining directions to a tourist The textbook spoke the universal truth: the proof is left as an exercise to the reader His lecture is just as inspirational

He's honestly a good guy, pretty funny at times too, but hardest class ever. Doesn't show many examples, and the ones he did show were hard for me to follow. Entire class is based around proofs. You're definitely gonna need to grab a few other textbooks on the subject in order for things to fall into place. Did curve the class by 5% at the end.

Prof. Denissov is a pretty good and quite clear lecturer. Homework was light--just a weekly assignment with typically 5 or so problems (some were fairly demanding). We had one quiz the whole semester. Test averages were typically quite low, but there was a significant curve at the end. He was not the best professor, but certainly not the worst.

His lectures are informative but challenging. Once you get used to his accent you will be ready to understand what he is trying to explain. His assignments are not too much but it takes time to solve all the problems. If you do well on all assignments then you will be good on tests, too. His exams are tough but well organized.

Shows hardly any examples in lecture and then tests you on concepts you haven't seen before. Lectures are meaningless to go to, you could probably do better by just looking at the textbook and learning more from that than his lectures.

If you want a class consisting of proofs that do not relate to any problems that are done on the exams, this is your guy. Practice problems are not similar to exams, and problems on exams are poorly worded. Overall worst professor I've ever had and I hope no one has to take any class taught by this professor.

Serguei is a good guy, and hes one of the more distinguished analysts at UW. He knows his stuff, but he doesnt put much effort into teaching; he shows up late, leaves early, and generally seems bored. However, his exams are fair and his curve is generous. I recommend going to his office hours, since he is much better one on one.

Just an awful professor in general. Came into the final exam and smirked at all the students because it was impossible. Lecture contains few examples, if any. One of my least favorite classes at UW because of him. 0/10. Avoid

Exam is really difficult and lecture is hard to understand. Even the instructions are unclear. You don't know what is the score to get an A and whether the exams have curve until the end of the semester. avoid if you can.

Although the first midterm was pretty easy, this class only gets harder and harder as it goes on. At the end the problems he sends out and for the practice exams start to make absolutely no sense, because he uses very strange wording and notation for many of them. Theres no resources on the internet to help because of the strange writing. Avoid

To put it simply this is a not an easy course. He is a fine professor but his lectures are dry. There is one moderately difficult homework assignment due each week. His tests are brutal and the class average is typically 60%. Fortunately there is a very large curve.

If you work hard and go to the lecture and discussion sessions, you will benefit a lot! His way of speaking is really tough for you to understand at the beginning, but you will get used to it (The way he speaks is really cute). Contents in the course is not hard, and he is explaining in a detailed way. His exams are relatively easier than others!

The professor is pretty nice and talks in a clear manner (get used to his accent haha) The materials are a little hard; but if you read materials after class, you can get on his pace. Exams are moderate. Overall, highly suggesting this professor!

lectures are super vague and extremely hard to follow. tests and homework have very little to do with lectures. honestly, you could not show up to lectures because you would be equally confused either way. tests are somewhat similar to practice problems, but literally you are completely on your own in this class.
Fantastic professor. If you're an analyst, or even want to think about being an analyst, Sergey is the professor for you. If you can't handle the heat get out of the kitchen.

Denissov is a pretty fine professor. Lectures are very rich in content. May take a little time to adjust to the theoretical proofs he does in lectures. But once you understand all the mathematical theorems and are able to solve problems using them, you should be just fine. If you have questions, just ask. Denissov explains things in rich content.

Analysis is always going to be super difficult, but Denissov didn't make it easier. He never posted solutions to the hw problems, only to the quiz and midterm. His office hours were the day the hw was due and before he assigned the next homework. He's not there to teach. Grading was weird--you get half credit for a solid attempt. HW was hard.

I thought Serguei explained concepts clearly and very well during lecture.  I ended up getting an A in the class and I didn't try too hard at all. Just pay attention, take good notes, and do the homework (as well as the practice problems before each exam) and you'll be just fine.

average UW-Madison Calc professor. Will take a week to get use to accent. When at lecture note he will explain the proof of why things work more then practical examples. If you practice with problems from other sources it wasn't that bad. Overall not best nor worst professor

Contrary to popular belief, if you need Calc 2 for you degree, this class should be a breeze for you. Do the homework and take notes in class and you should be able to get nearly perfect scores on the exams. ESPECIALLY if you do the practice exams he sends out. Very similar to the real exam; the problems are the same, just with different numbers.

Mid-terms are very easy. Just about basic concepts. Understand the concepts, you will definitely pass. But be careful about the final exam. It seems like the math department likes to make final exam difficult. He knew his material very well as he seldom made mistakes and paused during lectures. However, you may find his voice hypnotic.

Dennisov did a great job of explaining the material in lecture in one of the most failed classes on campus. Proofs were interestingenlightening, assignments tough but reinforced material well. Great board writing, entertaining accent and exams were extremely easy.

Lectures are generally filled with long proofs of the concepts and few examples. Review problems sent out before the exams were generally very similar to the exams so as long as you learn those processes to a T you should be fine.

Serguei is not your average math prof at UW. He's far more reasonable when it comes to testing. The numbers are simple and the concepts streamlined. The lectures are pretty boring and can be hard to interpret but that's expected right? Take him. Just massage the integral and you'll be fine. Remember that it's not calculus, it's just common sense.

He is definitely a great professor. Once you understand what certain things he says mean, it is easy to understand him. He is very funny and the tests are fairly easy. The assignments are what most people do poorly on because they only grade a couple problems. I would definitely choose him for this class again.

Very thick Russian accent which unintentionally became very funny. Lectures were kind of confusing so clarification from TA is helpful but TESTS ARE SO EASY. Generally about 6 Q's, very straightforward and simple
Lectures were clear with sample problems, go to discussion for clarification, midterms are short and problems are identical to provided sample problems Good professor, Russian accent

Serguei is a really nice guy, but is very confusing in his lectures. I stopped going halfway through the semester and just read the textbook to teach myself, which was much more successful. His exams are extremely fair and he also posts very helpful review guides before exams. He is probably one of the better Math 222 professors.

It's clear he is a very smart man and knows what he's talking about, but he doesn't really go about teaching the material in the best way. I was frequently confused about what he was talking about because he seemed to teach it in the most complicated ways. I mostly learned through my TA. However, the exams were really easy.

Don't take 222 with him unless you have taken Calc BC in high school. You will be lost in his class otherwise. For those who have taken Calc BC, I highly recommend Denissov. The lectures and homework are tough and very in- depth, but the exams are almost identical to the sample problems he gives.

Before exams he will put a practice exam on the website. The practice exams are extremely useful because they are very similar to the midterms so if you know how to do the practice questions you should be good. He will go over most of the practice exam questions in one or two of the lectures right before the midterm. Strongly recommend him.
Serguei Isn't the the most entertaining lecturer around but his tests are more than fair. If you're fine with teaching yourself a bit of the material this course should be a cake walk.

Calc II is debatably one of the most-failed classes at UW. Denissov does a great job explaining the ideas, but you're still going to need plenty of time out of class to do well in this class. Find the good TA and go to their reviews and office hours. The practice problems he gives out before midterms are extremely similar to the exams.

Lectures are long and it seems like all he does it just prove everything, but the TAs are super helpful.  When it comes to the exam, he is very straightforward and tells you what you need to be able to do which is extremely helpful for studying.  If I took 222 again I would definitely still pick him.

Yes his lecture is long, he loves proving stuff that never appear on exams etc but this guy is inspirational. He tries to explain the essence of calculus to you instead of giving you exam-cracking tricks that make you look good on your GPA but doesn't do anything to training your brain. Once you understand him you will enjoy his lectures.

He complicates everything way more than it needs to be. He focuses on proofs as opposed to examples which is pretty much no help. The UW math textbooks suck, basically my TA saved my life in this class. Denissov is kinda funny though in his own quirky way, which makes lectures more bearable. His accent is thick but you get used to it quickly.

A nice guy who knows what he is talking about, but lectures are hard to follow. His board organization skills are poor and instead of rewriting a slightly different problem he will erase some parts of it and write in new stuff. Exams are not bad if you know what you're doing and his grading scale is very fair. Most likely will get through 222w him

He is alright at explaining concepts, but if I hadn't taken AP Calc in high school, I wouldn't have understood much.  Lectures make simple things seem complicated. Exams are difficult, and since they're graded out of only five points, there is little room for even the smallest errors.  Curve at the end of the semester is very generous, though.

He fails to make the content very interesting, but he is adequate. Exams are only minor variations of the sample questions he gives aside from the last problem. Grading system is unforgiving (each problem is only worth 1 point on HW/midterms). Despite this being Honors Calc I, we covered less than regular Calc (eg. no related rates; substitution).

Definitely avoid this professor. His lectures did not relate to the tests at all really. All he did was prove pointless things on the board. The tests were also very hard, and he basically threw anything at you and didn't prepare you at all. Without previous calc experience this class would have been impossible.
He really only proved things and didn't use examples. Don't take if you can choose. Also the "lecture notes" as a textbook were very unclear.
AVOID!!!! Denissov is a useless professor that has no interest in his students. You won't learn calculus with him...

if you have not had calc before, this class is going to be hard. id definitely suggest getting a tutor. if you took calc in high school and did ok youll be fine. i barely studied and got an A in the course so if youre pretty good at math dont let these review scare you. do the homework and ask questions on what you dont get and youll be fine

Terrible professor,not personable&terrible at explaining!!Always goes over proofs that will never be tested. Book used is compiled lecture notes with no examples&confusing explanations.Midterms are ridiculously hard,average was 50%.Best he gave us for idea of grade was “good,ok,&should consider dropping.”TERRIBLE PROFESSOR!SWITCH WHILE YOU CAN!!!!

Denissov singlehandedly destroyed my gap. I have never gotten less than an ab in math even in college but in this class I barely passed. His tests don't make sense and at the end of them you wonder when did I learn this ? He is a very smart man I just hope he realises teaching is not his calling

Least favorite teacher.  He does not explain how to solve problems or how the exams will be graded.  Especially avoid if you have not taken calc before! Hint: copy everything on the board and find a math genius to decode the nonsense later!

He is a really smart guy, using complex notations and teaching tricky problems. However, he knows his material very well, as well as math. He tries to make you understand the concepts, not just be able to memorize equations and plug in numbers. Very nice man!
Hilarious professor. Spends a lot of time on proofs which is useless when compared to exams though. Recommended only if you have taken calculus before!
Lectures are boring, generally solves proofs.  Having a good TA helps.  Exams were difficult, even having taken calculus in high school

Lectures are extremely hard to follow- he does mostly proofs that are of little use in solving any of the problems. Studying in groups and going to office hours are essential- tests are very difficult, and the average is always about 50%. Hard class to do well in even if you've had calc before. Having a helpful, clear TA helps a ton.

He is almost too smart for his own good- he is not able to communicate well to an entry level calc class. Though the class is supposed to be about applications, he gets way too much into theory during lecture.  You can make it through this class, but you will have to rely on your TA and lecture notes to teach yourself.

He is Russian with a heavy accent, but you'll get used to it eventually. Very smart and tends to skip over some of the "basic" steps, so stay alert. I went to his office hours, nice guy and helpful too. His tests are hard and besides; this is college Calc. Don't expect to be spoon fed everything. Study hard, do lots of problems and you'll be fine.

Definitely the worst math teacher I've ever had. His exams are ridiculously hard compared to everything else and the grading scale is very harsh. The exams also only have 4-5 questions. The text is also useless, it isn't a standard book, instead its a collection of lecture notes that don't help. I would not recommend him to anyone.

In the beginning of the year I literally could not understand a word he was saying, now I can pick up a good amount but not all. His midterms are ridiculously hard and the average for the first two were 50% and I had never seen those problems before. The TA's are essential or I wouldn't learn anything

Very Brilliant teacher! He really knows his stuff! A little difficult to follow at first because of his accent, but once you get used to it, he is a great teacher! The proofs of theorems are unnecessary and can be confusing, but those are never on the tests. He goes over sample questions pretty clearly. Very nice guy, def go to his office hours.

The Professor is really intelligent but that is more of a negative in a first level Math class. The midterms are extremely difficult and he always gives questions you have never seen before in order to make you apply hat you supposedly learned. His lectures are difficult to follow. Ta's basically teach the class.

Worst professor I've ever had and I haven't been through the semester yet. His lecture structure is poor, his grade structure is poorer. I loath going to his lecture because I know I will have to sit through a power lecture of proofs and not the important concepts that I need to know to apply in homework.
Tough Class. Proofs are everything. Not the class for you if you need more than a vague proof to understand math. Curve is hard. Decent teacher and office hours really help.

Lectures were useful, he did a good job of providing examples and he was helpful enough (although not particularly friendly or personable). He's brilliant and clearly knows his stuff (he rarely even uses notes in lecture), but his curve was weird and grading was vague. Exams were easy, but if you made even a tiny mistake you were SCREWED.

Sometimes he did not write the main points on the board so you have to pay attention to what he said. Harsh grading system, rather heavy Russian English. But he is really helpful if you consult him. He is willing to repeat the whole thing to you.

The lectures where useless except for review sections. He gave out sample questions before every exam and answered them in review sessions. You could bring several pages into each exam (more than enough for the sample questions). Best of all the sample questions were NEAR IDENTICAL to the exam. Homework was harder than tests.

The worst teacher I've ever had. He writes 1000 things on the board that he doesn't explain and don't show up on the homework. It was also apparent he doesn't care about his students or teaching. Whenever I attempted to go ask questions he made it obvious I was a bother to him. He said the entire class was "trivial" several times.

The BEST math professor I've ever had.  His lectures are a bit tough to sit through because he doesn't write down everything on the board clearly, but if you go in and talk to him-he explains EVERYTHING.  It was a tough class though, a 50%=B and a 65%=A (and to get that 65%, you'd really have to work hard for it). And homework was 50% of our grade.

Denissov could be described as apathetic at best. He teaches the blackboard how to do math without ever once explaining why. All that I learned in his class, I learned from the TA. It's an easy A, and the curriculum is interesting by itself, just don't expect things like...academic merit, scholarship, challenge, etc.
Totally unhelpful + stringent grading policy = bad teacher.

He was interested in teaching and enjoyed lecturing. He was down to earth, curve was tremendous, poor students were in class. Amount of homework was 1-2 hours per week. One thing about the class I didn't like was that the grader was not the professor, so if I would ask if something was ok to do on the exam, the grader took points off.

This is the perfect class for anyone who doesnt want to go to class. 50% of your grade is homework, and it's easy to get a perfect on the homework. If you get a 50% in the class, it's a BC.A 60% isa B, a 75% is an AB, andan 85% is an A.Lectures don't help, so don't go. If you get perfect on the HW and 50% on each midterm, you get an AB in the class

He's pretty hard to understand in the beginning, but once you get use to the accent, it's a lot clearer. Pretty harsh on grading (class avg was 29/60 for  midterm). He's okay though, but kind of hard to understand. Discussion sections will help.
Not a bad professor. His lectures make us confusing, but exams are pretty easy if you did well homeworks. If you want to study rigorous proofs, however, please find other professor.

Self-teaching is a necessity for this class, even with prior calc knowledge. Lectures can often become confusing. He is helpful and cares about the class. The grading scale was forgiving. He speaks clearly with an accent and his writing is usually legible except he sometimes doesnt erase the board well. Exams are tricky but not hard. Do homework!
good
well, the other day he went through a one hour long proof that nobody understood. at the end of it he said 'so this is basically the answer to everything'  I LoLed, so did half of the class
Great Professor.  He explains the material well, but he runs a tough course.  He also has a very nice accent.
Most Common Phrase: "This is elementary!" The class is taught at a 600+ level and is quite abstract. BUT... the russian accent is amusing if the material gets boring.
